[[228]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-228) The addition of leucine (0.1g/kg) to whey protein (0.2g/kg) might further enhance the benefits of whey protein; whether increasing the protein content to get more leucine (vicariously through whey) confers the same benefit is unknown 16.3 Zinc [Zinc](/supplements/zinc/) is an essential mineral involved in bone, hormone, and enzyme metabolism. The addition of 30mg zinc to a whey drink in the frail (hospitalized) elderly is able to enhance IGF-1 secretion from 22.4+/-4.7% to 48.2+/-14.3% (average 215% more secretion) and further better activities of daily living. [[229]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-229) Whey, as well as casein, are able to increase IGF-1 secretion and may be of benefit to older individuals in reducing frailty. [[230]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-230) [[231]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-231) 16.4 Digestive Enzymes Protein digestive enzymes are sometimes paired with protein to 'enhance absorption'. One open labelled study has been conducted on the matter (funded by Triarco, supplier of patented enzymes used; conducted independently) found that pairing 2.5g or 5g of a proteolytic enzyme blend (Aminogen) with 50g whey protein concentrate found that the addition of enzymes increased the area-under-curve (AUC) of amino acids in the blood and 3.5-fold with 5g Aminogen. [[232]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-232) Serum amino acids were measured for 4 hours after ingestion, and 24-hour nitrogen excretion assessed by urine was lower in the Aminogen group. [[232]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-232) Aminogen is a blend of enzymes from Aspergillus niger and Aspergillus oryzae, these results may apply to other compounds with protein digestive abilities such as [Bromelain](/supplements/bromelain/). May accelerate the rate of absorption for whey concentrate, but more studies would need to be conducted for conclusions. The cessation of measuring at 4 hours after a 50g bolus of protein may favor the faster absorbing protein, when it is theoretically possible that there would be no significant AUC difference if measured at 8 hours 16.5 HAMLET HAMLET is an acronym for Human a-lactalbumin made lethal to tumour cells, and is the quaternary protein a-lactalbumin from whey bound with oleic acid (found in [olive oil](/foods/olive-oil/) as well as [eggs)](https://examine.com/supplements/egg-chicken/). [[233]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-233) The binding of oleic acid to a-lactalbumin partially unfolds the protein, which is causative of the increased anti-cancer potential (via killing tumors) as native a-lactalbumin does not inherently attack tumors. [[233]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-233) It was first discovered in 1995 [[234]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-234) and intentionally created in 2000 through an ion-exchange procedure in a medium with oleic acid [[235]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-235) and now has additional preparation methods. [[236]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-236) Beyond cancer cells, HAMLET appears to have potency in killing the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae. [[237]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-237) [[235]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-235) [[238]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-238) HAMLET is the most well researched, but Oleic Acid has been shown to form complexes with bovine -lactalbumin (component of Whey Protein) [[239]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-239) where binding of oleic acid induced thermal stabilization of -lactalbumin and was as effective as HAMLET in inducing cell death in HEp-2 cells. [[239]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-239) Additionally, a-lactalbumin that is derived from cows milk (Bovine a-lactalbumin) is referred to as BAMLET. [[240]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-240) BAMLET and other variants of HAMLET such as the aforementioned complex of oleic acid and -lactalbumin have comparable cytotoxicity to cancer cells. [[241]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-241) [[242]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-242) One study investigating the effects of heat treatment noted that unfolding of the protein (denaturation) caused an enhanced subsequent production of BAMLET in vitro, but eventually the heat could cumulatively degrade the a-lactalbumin precursor and hinder BAMLET production. [[240]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-240) These results contrast earlier hypothesis' that changes to protein confirmation could abolish the effects of HAMLET/BAMLET. [[243]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-243) One the complex itself is formed, it has either equal to or lesser stability than the protein it was formed from; with one study noting that HAMLET was denatured at 15°C less than a-lactalbumin. [[244]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-244) A promising anti-cancer complex of whey protein and olive oil components; no in vivo studies currently exist so beyond noting its potential no conclusions can be made as to efficacy or whether it can be digested or formed in vivo after consumption of the components 17. Safety and Toxicity 17.1 Pregnancy Whey is already a component of human breast milk, [[245]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-245) [[246]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-246) as are many of its bioactive peptides such as alpha-lactalbumin, which is seen as good for infant nutrition. [[12]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-12) Beyond that, whey is commonly added to infant formulaes due to its benefits associated with infant health (although usually in a hydrolyzed form, which might reduces the allergic potential yet has not been shown to have benefits over breast milk [[247]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-247)). No human evidence exists directly assessing whether or not whey consumption per se is good or bad for infant health when consumed by a mother during pregnancy or lactation; one study in mice found that general overconsumption of protein (40% of the diet by calories) during pregnancy could slightly reduce birth weight of the pups, and during lactation it reduced the mRNA of bioactive proteins in the breast. [[248]](/supplements/whey-protein/research/#ref-248) No compelling evidence to discourage usage in pregnancy, and whey as a naturally component of cheese and milk (consumed routinely during pregnancy) suggests moderate usage of whey protein is fine.
